# Introduction

This document contains full model for RI-CLPM analysis for article about social dominance orientations and trust in trade unions. Controls used in this analysis corresponds to **trust in institutions, political ideology, income deciles, eduations, age and sex**. First, fit measures are showed for all calculated models. Second, fit mesasures of unconstrained and constrained models are compared. Third, fit measures are compared between models. Fourth, coefficients of the chosen model are interpretated. At the end of the document principal findigs are synthetized.

```{r}
######## PROCESSING #############

# 7. Compare indices -------------------
# 7.1 Create text objects ----------------

## Estimate variance between
bwcomp <- ' 
    # Create the between components
    RI_x =~ 1*dom_index1 + 1*dom_index2 + 1*dom_index3 + 1*dom_index4
    RI_y =~ 1*conf_sin1 + 1*conf_sin2 + 1*conf_sin3 + 1*conf_sin4
    RI_z =~ 1*conf_index1 + 1*conf_index2 + 1*conf_index3 + 1*conf_index4
    RI_w =~ 1*ideol1 + 1*ideol2 + 1*ideol3 + 1*ideol4
    RI_v =~ 1*decile1 + 1*decile2 + 1*decile3 + 1*decile4
    RI_t =~ 1*educ1 + 1*educ2 + 1*educ3 + 1*educ4

    
    # Create the components within
    DOM_INDEX1 =~ 1*dom_index1
    DOM_INDEX2 =~ 1*dom_index2
    DOM_INDEX3 =~ 1*dom_index3
    DOM_INDEX4 =~ 1*dom_index4

    
    CS1 =~ 1*conf_sin1
    CS2 =~ 1*conf_sin2
    CS3 =~ 1*conf_sin3
    CS4 =~ 1*conf_sin4

    CONF_INDEX1 =~ 1*conf_index1
    CONF_INDEX2 =~ 1*conf_index2
    CONF_INDEX3 =~ 1*conf_index3
    CONF_INDEX4 =~ 1*conf_index4
  
    IDEOL1 =~ 1*ideol1
    IDEOL2 =~ 1*ideol2
    IDEOL3 =~ 1*ideol3
    IDEOL4 =~ 1*ideol4
    
    DECILE1 =~ 1*decile1
    DECILE2 =~ 1*decile2
    DECILE3 =~ 1*decile3
    DECILE4 =~ 1*decile4
    
    EDUC1 =~ 1*educ1
    EDUC2 =~ 1*educ2
    EDUC3 =~ 1*educ3
    EDUC4 =~ 1*educ4

    
    # Construct the measurement error variances to zero
    dom_index1 ~~ 0*dom_index1
    dom_index2 ~~ 0*dom_index2
    dom_index3 ~~ 0*dom_index3
    dom_index4 ~~ 0*dom_index4
    conf_sin1 ~~ 0*conf_sin1
    conf_sin2 ~~ 0*conf_sin2
    conf_sin3 ~~ 0*conf_sin3
    conf_sin4 ~~ 0*conf_sin4
          '

## Estimate variance within
varcov <- ' 
    # Estimate the covariance between the components within t=1
    DOM_INDEX1 ~~ CS1
    CONF_INDEX1 ~~ CS1 
    DOM_INDEX1 ~~ CONF_INDEX1
    IDEOL1 ~~ CS1 
    DOM_INDEX1 ~~ IDEOL1
    DECILE1 ~~ CS1 
    DOM_INDEX1 ~~ DECILE1
    EDUC1 ~~ CS1 
    DOM_INDEX1 ~~ EDUC1
    
    # Estimate the covariances between the residuals of the within component.
    DOM_INDEX2 ~~ CS2
    CONF_INDEX2 ~~ CS2 
    DOM_INDEX2 ~~ CONF_INDEX2
    IDEOL2 ~~ CS2 
    DOM_INDEX2 ~~ IDEOL2
    DECILE2 ~~ CS2 
    DOM_INDEX2 ~~ DECILE2
    EDUC2 ~~ CS2 
    DOM_INDEX2 ~~ EDUC2
    
    DOM_INDEX3 ~~ CS3
    CONF_INDEX3 ~~ CS3 
    DOM_INDEX3 ~~ CONF_INDEX3
    IDEOL3 ~~ CS3 
    DOM_INDEX3 ~~ IDEOL3
    DECILE3 ~~ CS3 
    DOM_INDEX3 ~~ DECILE3
    EDUC3 ~~ CS3 
    DOM_INDEX3 ~~ EDUC3
    
    DOM_INDEX4 ~~ CS4
    CONF_INDEX4 ~~ CS4 
    DOM_INDEX4 ~~ CONF_INDEX4
    IDEOL4 ~~ CS4 
    DOM_INDEX4 ~~ IDEOL4
    DECILE4 ~~ CS4 
    DOM_INDEX4 ~~ DECILE4
    EDUC4 ~~ CS4 
    DOM_INDEX4 ~~ EDUC4
    
    
    # Estimate the residual variances of the within component
    DOM_INDEX1 ~~ DOM_INDEX1 # Variances
    DOM_INDEX2 ~~ DOM_INDEX2 # Residual variances
    DOM_INDEX3 ~~ DOM_INDEX3 
    DOM_INDEX4 ~~ DOM_INDEX4 
    
    CS1 ~~ CS1 # Variances
    CS2 ~~ CS2 # Residual variances
    CS3 ~~ CS3 
    CS4 ~~ CS4 
    
    CONF_INDEX1 ~~ CONF_INDEX1 # Variances
    CONF_INDEX2 ~~ CONF_INDEX2
    CONF_INDEX3 ~~ CONF_INDEX3
    CONF_INDEX4 ~~ CONF_INDEX4
    
    IDEOL1 ~~ IDEOL1 # Variances
    IDEOL2 ~~ IDEOL2
    IDEOL3 ~~ IDEOL3
    IDEOL4 ~~ IDEOL4
    
    DECILE1 ~~ DECILE1 # Variances
    DECILE2 ~~ DECILE2
    DECILE3 ~~ DECILE3
    DECILE4 ~~ DECILE4
    
    EDUC1 ~~ EDUC1 # Variances
    EDUC2 ~~ EDUC2
    EDUC3 ~~ EDUC3
    EDUC4 ~~ EDUC4
    
    # Estimate the variance and covariance between RIs.
    RI_x ~~ RI_x
    RI_y ~~ RI_y
    RI_x ~~ RI_y
    
    RI_z ~~ RI_z
    RI_z ~~ RI_y
    RI_z ~~ RI_x
    
    RI_w ~~ RI_w
    RI_w ~~ RI_y
    RI_w ~~ RI_x
    
    RI_v ~~ RI_v
    RI_v ~~ RI_y
    RI_v ~~ RI_x

    RI_t ~~ RI_t
    RI_t ~~ RI_y
    RI_t ~~ RI_x
    
    # Set the correlation between the RI and components within t=1 to zero
    RI_x ~~ 0*DOM_INDEX1
    RI_x ~~ 0*CS1
    RI_x ~~ 0*CONF_INDEX1
    RI_x ~~ 0*IDEOL1
    RI_x ~~ 0*DECILE1
    RI_x ~~ 0*EDUC1
    
    RI_y ~~ 0*DOM_INDEX1
    RI_y ~~ 0*CS1
    RI_y ~~ 0*CONF_INDEX1
    RI_y ~~ 0*IDEOL1
    RI_y ~~ 0*DECILE1
    RI_y ~~ 0*EDUC1
    
    RI_z ~~ 0*DOM_INDEX1
    RI_z ~~ 0*CS1
    RI_z ~~ 0*CONF_INDEX1
    RI_z ~~ 0*IDEOL1
    RI_z ~~ 0*DECILE1
    RI_z ~~ 0*EDUC1
    
    RI_w ~~ 0*DOM_INDEX1
    RI_w ~~ 0*CS1
    RI_w ~~ 0*CONF_INDEX1
    RI_w ~~ 0*IDEOL1
    RI_w ~~ 0*DECILE1
    RI_w ~~ 0*EDUC1
    
    RI_v ~~ 0*DOM_INDEX1
    RI_v ~~ 0*CS1
    RI_v ~~ 0*CONF_INDEX1
    RI_v ~~ 0*IDEOL1
    RI_v ~~ 0*DECILE1
    RI_v ~~ 0*EDUC1
    
    RI_t ~~ 0*DOM_INDEX1
    RI_t ~~ 0*CS1
    RI_t ~~ 0*CONF_INDEX1
    RI_t ~~ 0*IDEOL1
    RI_t ~~ 0*DECILE1
    RI_t ~~ 0*EDUC1
          '


## Estimating regressions

## Autoregressive: Free
a1 <- '
    DOM_INDEX2 ~ DOM_INDEX1        
    DOM_INDEX3 ~ DOM_INDEX2 
    DOM_INDEX4 ~ DOM_INDEX3
    CS2 ~ CS1
    CS3 ~ CS2
    CS4 ~ CS3
    CONF_INDEX4 ~ CONF_INDEX3
    CONF_INDEX3 ~ CONF_INDEX2
    CONF_INDEX2 ~ CONF_INDEX1
    IDEOL4 ~ IDEOL3
    IDEOL3 ~ IDEOL2
    IDEOL2 ~ IDEOL1
    DECILE4 ~ DECILE3
    DECILE3 ~ DECILE2
    DECILE2 ~ DECILE1
    EDUC4 ~ EDUC3
    EDUC3 ~ EDUC2
    EDUC2 ~ EDUC1
'

### Autoregressive: constrained
a2 <- '
    DOM_INDEX2 ~ a*DOM_INDEX1      
    DOM_INDEX3 ~ a*DOM_INDEX2 
    DOM_INDEX4 ~ a*DOM_INDEX3 
    CS2 ~ i*CS1
    CS3 ~ i*CS2
    CS4 ~ i*CS3
    CONF_INDEX4 ~ o*CONF_INDEX3
    CONF_INDEX3 ~ o*CONF_INDEX2
    CONF_INDEX2 ~ o*CONF_INDEX1
    IDEOL4 ~ p*IDEOL3

    IDEOL2 ~ p*IDEOL1
    DECILE4 ~ q*DECILE3

    DECILE2 ~ q*DECILE1

'

### Forward: free

    DOM_INDEX2 ~ DOM_INDEX1 + CS1 + CONF_INDEX1 + IDEOL1 + DECILE1 + EDUC1 + g*edad1         
    DOM_INDEX3 ~ DOM_INDEX2 + CS2 + CONF_INDEX2 + IDEOL2 + DECILE2 + EDUC2 + g*edad1

    CS4 ~ CS3

    CONF_INDEX3 ~ CONF_INDEX2

### Backward: free
c1 <- '

    CS2 ~ DOM_INDEX1 + CS1 + CONF_INDEX1 + IDEOL1 + DECILE1 + EDUC1 + n*edad1

    CS4 ~ DOM_INDEX3 + CS3 + CONF_INDEX3 + IDEOL3 + DECILE3 + EDUC3 + n*edad1
    CONF_INDEX4 ~ CONF_INDEX3
    CONF_INDEX3 ~ CONF_INDEX2
    CONF_INDEX2 ~ CONF_INDEX1
    IDEOL4 ~ IDEOL3
    IDEOL3 ~ IDEOL2
    IDEOL2 ~ IDEOL1
    DECILE4 ~ DECILE3
    DECILE3 ~ DECILE2
    DECILE2 ~ DECILE1
    EDUC4 ~ EDUC3

    EDUC2 ~ EDUC1
'

### Backward: constrained
c2 <- '
    DOM_INDEX2 ~ a*DOM_INDEX1        
    DOM_INDEX3 ~ a*DOM_INDEX2  
    DOM_INDEX4 ~ a*DOM_INDEX3
    CS2 ~ h*DOM_INDEX1 + i*CS1 + j*CONF_INDEX1 + k*IDEOL1 + l*DECILE1 + m*EDUC1 + n*edad1 
    CS3 ~ h*DOM_INDEX2 + i*CS2 + j*CONF_INDEX2 + k*IDEOL2 + l*DECILE2 + m*EDUC2 + n*edad1

# 7.2 Create GOF ----------------

### Vector with models
models <- c("a1","a2","b1","b2","c1","c2","d1","d2")

### Estimate each model within a for loop

fit <- list() # Create empty list for storing lavaan objects

for (i in models){
  fit[[i]] <- lavaan(model = c(bwcomp,get(i),varcov),
                     data = elsoc, 
                     estimator = "MLR", 
                     missing = "FIML",
                     group = "sexo1",
                     meanstructure = T, 
                     int.ov.free = T) # Execute estimate
}

### Save the GOFs of each model in a list from a for loop.

gofdt <- list() # Crear lista vacia

for (i in names(fit)){
  x <- fitMeasures(fit[[i]])[c("chisq.scaled","df.scaled","pvalue.scaled","cfi.scaled","tli.scaled","rmsea.scaled",
                               "srmr_mplus","aic","bic","bic2","logl","npar","scaling.factor.h0")]
  gofdt[[i]] <- setNames(as.numeric(x),
                         c("X2","df","pvalue","CFI","TLI","RMSEA","SRMR","AIC","BIC","aBIC","LL","par","LLcorrectf"))} # Extract gof indexes

gofdt <- data.table(m=names(gofdt),dplyr::bind_rows(gofdt)) # Transfer to datatable format the gof indexes

# 7.3 Compare GOF ---------------

### Create function

gof.comp  = function(data, pairs,
                     measures = c("CFI","TLI","RMSEA","SRMR",
                                  "AIC","BIC","aBIC","par","LL")){
  comp <- list()
  for (i in 1:length(pairs)){
    gof <- data
    nest <- pairs[[i]][1]
    full <- pairs[[i]][2]
    delta <- NULL
    for (k in measures){
      delta[paste0(k,"_D")] <- gof[m==nest, get(k)] - gof[m==full, get(k)]
    }
    par_LLcorf_nest <- gof[m==nest,par]*gof[m==nest,LLcorrectf]
    par_LLcorf_full <- gof[m==full,par]*gof[m==full,LLcorrectf]
    delta["CD"] <- (par_LLcorf_nest-par_LLcorf_full)/delta["par_D"]
    delta["TRd"] <- (-2*delta["LL_D"])/delta["CD"]
    delta["TRd_df"] <- gof[m==full, "par"] - gof[m==nest, "par"]
    delta["TRd_pvalue"] <- pchisq(as.numeric(delta["TRd"]),
                                  as.numeric(delta["TRd_df"]), lower.tail = F)
    comp[[paste0(nest," vs. ",full,sep="")]] <- delta
  }
  comp <- data.table(comp=names(comp),dplyr::bind_rows(comp))
  return(comp)
}

### Test models 1 and 2

comp1 <- gof.comp(data = gofdt, pairs = list(c("a2","a1"),c("b2","b1"),c("c2","c1"),c("d2","d1")))

### Test models A-D

comp2 <- gof.comp(data = gofdt, pairs = list(c("a2","b2"),c("a2","c2"),c("a2","d2"),c("b2","d2"),c("c2","d2")))
```

# Analysis
## Fit measures


```{r fit}
kableExtra::kable(gofdt,digits = 3,
                  caption = "Fit measueres for RI-CLPM models between SDO & Trust in Trade Unions") %>%   kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T)
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:fit) git measures of all calculated models are showed. In general, all models shows fit measures that are above the cutoff recommended by the literature (CFI >.90).

```{r fit-comp}
kableExtra::kable(comp1,digits = 3,
                  caption = "Comparison of fit measures (between unconstrained and constrained models)") %>% kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T)

```

At the Table \@ref(tab:fit-comp) fit measures of unconstrained and constrained models are showed. Following Rutkowski & Svetina (2014) and Chen (2007) differences suggest that unconstrained models should be retained (ΔCFI < 0.02, ΔRMSEA < 0.03) for models a, b and c. Estimates for comparisson of model d shows mixed evidence, with a CFI above 0.02 and a RMSEA smaller than 0.03.

```{r fit-comp2}
kable(comp2,digits = 3,
      caption = "Comparison of fit measures between (models A-D)") %>% kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T)
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:fit-comp2)

## Interpretations

### Forward models

```{r bw1}
param_b1 <- data.table(parameterEstimates(fit[["b1"]]))

kable(param_b1[op=="~~" & rhs %in% c("RI_x","RI_y"), !"label"], digits = 3,
      caption = "B1 model interpretations of between components") %>% kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T)
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:bw1), estimates for the random intercepts of forward unconstrained models are showed. Both random intercepts have significant variance. This implies that there are stable differences between individuals with respect to their expected scores in trust in trade unions and social dominance orientation[^1].

[^1]: If the variance were not different from 0, it would mean that there are very few stable differences between units and that each individual fluctuates around the same grand mean over time.

```{r w1}

param_b1$group[param_b1$group == 1] <- "Men"
param_b1$group[param_b1$group == 2] <- "Women"

kable(param_b1[op=="~" & rhs %in% param_b1$rhs[c(57:77)] & lhs %in% param_b1$lhs[c(57:77)] , !"label"],
      digits = 3,
      caption = "B1 model interpretations of within components") %>% 
  kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T) %>% 
  row_spec(c(2,9,16,23,30,37), bold = T, color = "white", background = "#9CE599") # Añadir destacado
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:w1) estimates of the crosslagged regressions are showed for the forward unconstrained models. The analysis reveals a negative effect between SDO and trust in trade unions at waves 3 and 4 **in mens**. In details, a deviation of one point above the average level of trust in trade unions at wave 3 predicts a deviation of `r round(param_b1$est[param_b1$lhs == "DOM_INDEX4" & param_b1$rhs == "CS3"],3)` in SDO during wave 4, controlling for deviations from the expected score in SDO and trust in institutions, political ideology, income deciles, education and age. 

```{r bw2}
param_b2 <- data.table(parameterEstimates(fit[["b2"]]))

kable(param_b2[op=="~~" & rhs %in% c("RI_x","RI_y"), !"label"], digits = 3,
            caption = "B2 model interpretations of between components") %>% kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T)
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:bw2) estimates for the random intercepts of forward constrained models are showed. Both random intercepts have significant variance. This implies that there are stable differences between individuals with respect to their expected scores in trust in trade unions and social dominance orientation.

```{r w2}

param_b2$group[param_b2$group == 1] <- "Men"
param_b2$group[param_b2$group == 2] <- "Women"

kable(param_b2[op=="~" & rhs %in% param_b2$rhs[c(57:77)] & lhs %in% param_b2$lhs[c(57:77)] , !"label"],
      digits = 3,
      caption = "B2 model interpretations of within components") %>% 
  kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T) %>% 
  row_spec(c(2,9,16,23,30,37), bold = T, color = "white", background = "#9CE599") # Añadir destacado
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:w2) estimates of the crosslagged regressions are showed for the forward constrained models. It is observed that a deviation of one point above the average level of trust in trade unions predicts a negative deviation of `r round(param_b2$est[param_b2$lhs == "DOM_INDEX4" & param_b2$rhs == "CS3"],3)` in SDO during the next measurement, controlling for deviations from the expected score in all the other variables.

### Bidirectional models

```{r bw3}
param_d1 <- data.table(parameterEstimates(fit[["d1"]]))

kable(param_d1[op=="~~" & rhs %in% c("RI_x","RI_y"), !"label"], digits = 3,
      caption = "D1 model interpretations of between components") %>% kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T)
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:bw3), estimates for the random intercepts of bidirectional unconstrained models are showed. Both random intercepts have significant variance. This implies that there are stable differences between individuals with respect to their expected scores in trust in trade unions and social dominance orientation.

```{r w3}

param_d1$group[param_d1$group == 1] <- "Men"
param_d1$group[param_d1$group == 2] <- "Women"

kable(param_d1[op=="~" & rhs %in% param_d1$rhs[c(57:77)] & lhs %in% param_d1$lhs[c(57:77)] , !"label"],
      digits = 3,
      caption = "D1 model interpretations of within components") %>% 
  kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive"), full_width = T) %>% 
  row_spec(c(2,9,16,23,30,37), bold = T, color = "white", background = "#9CE599") # Añadir destacado
```

At the Table \@ref(tab:w3) estimates of the crosslagged regressions are showed for the bidirectional unconstrained models. The analysis reveals a negative effect between SDO and trust in trade unions at waves 3 and 4 **in mens**. In details, a deviation of one point above the average level of trust in trade unions at wave 3 predicts a deviation of `r round(param_d1$est[param_d1$lhs == "DOM_INDEX4" & param_d1$rhs == "CS3"],3)` in SDO during wave 4, controlling for deviations from the expected score in SDO and trust in institutions, political ideology, income deciles, education and age.
